review: Initially, I expected a book about birding to be tedious, but I found it surprisingly engaging. It inspired me to head outside and see what birds I could spot!

I fell in love with John and Celeste. It's refreshing to see older adults find love, as their experiences often present unique situations not typically explored with younger characters. Celeste's journey to embrace life after divorce while staying connected to her daughter was deeply relatable. John, though not verbose, was a man of action, and I found him utterly endearing.
This debut novel is truly impressive, and I eagerly anticipate what this author will deliver next.

The book artfully delves into themes of love, self-discovery, and life transitions, particularly for older adults, presenting them with remarkable authenticity. It was a joy to witness such genuine portrayals.
I was pleasantly surprised by how much I loved this book. It turned out to be a refreshing and enjoyable read!
conclusion: This book was a delightful surprise, with relatable characters, heartfelt themes, and an engaging plot. It left me inspired and eager for more from the author.

review: The novel presents a unique and engaging premise: a recently divorced woman enters a fake dating arrangement with an aspiring birding guide to assist him in winning a bird count competition. This creative setup adds a refreshing twist to the story.

I appreciated that the two main characters were in their 40s, as this added maturity and relatability to their journey. Their evolution from a friends-with-benefits arrangement to something deeper was compellingly executed.
The writing was engaging, and the pacing maintained my interest throughout. The author's skillful blend of humor, romance, and emotional depth was truly impressive.

This heartfelt story explores emotional depth through the characters' struggles with relationship baggage. It thoughtfully addresses themes of second chances at love and personal growth, resonating deeply with me.
The romance was both steamy and satisfying, striking a perfect balance between passion and emotional depth. The progression of their relationship felt organic and gratifying.
conclusion: This 2024 debut novel is a heartfelt, steamy, and emotionally rich story about second chances at love and overcoming personal baggage. With well-developed characters, a unique premise, and a satisfying romantic arc, it‚Äôs a highly recommended read.

review: This story's meet-cute was hilarious, a touch sexy, and simply delightful. I loved learning about birding, especially knowing the author is an avid birder herself‚Äîit felt authentic and inspired me to notice the birds in my own neighborhood. Plus, who knew birdwatching could be so steamy? The memorable scenes, like the kiss by the mural and the closet moment, have firmly lodged themselves in my mind.

The main character, John, exudes a captivating blend of sexy lumberjack and librarian vibes, showcasing both quiet confidence and thoroughness. His enthusiastic approach to consent is commendable. I appreciated the refreshing age of the protagonists, both in their 40s, as older characters are often underrepresented in romance novels. The supporting characters, Chris and Maria, serve as excellent foils, adding depth to the story. Additionally, the relationship between Celeste and her daughter, Morgan, is beautifully realistic and heartwarming.
From the very beginning, I couldn't help but giggle at its sheer adorableness, and I knew I was completely hooked.
conclusion: All in all, I really loved this book. It was engaging, funny, and heartwarming, with well-developed characters and unique elements like birding that added depth. Highly recommend!

review: The story centers on a delightful mix-up in which Celeste agrees to be John's fake girlfriend to make his ex jealous, only to find out he truly needs a birding partner for a 42-day competition. This unique premise seamlessly blends humor, romance, and the niche world of birding, creating an engaging narrative.

In this engaging story, John and Celeste, both in their 40s, navigate personal challenges that shape their journey. John, newly unemployed, contemplates launching a bird-watching company and harbors a passion for woodworking, while Celeste, a single mother on the brink of an empty nest, embraces a "say yes" mentality following her divorce. Their distinct personalities shine through: John is quiet, introspective, and kind, while Celeste is adventurous, spontaneous, and firmly avoiding romantic entanglements. The fake dating trope injects delightful tension, especially as their chemistry ignites at a party, where their dialogue sizzles with heat and flirtation. Memorable interactions in John's workshop further elevate the romantic tension, making the story a captivating exploration of love and self-discovery.

The dialogue is sharp, witty, and engaging, especially during the party scene and the characters' discussions about birding and woodworking. The writing skillfully blends humor, romance, and emotional depth, creating a story that is both entertaining and heartfelt.

The book delves into themes of self-discovery, embracing new adventures, and finding joy in the unexpected. Celeste's insight that birding is about appreciating the small details reflects her own journey of rediscovery. Additionally, the narrative explores healing from past relationships and highlights the significance of taking risks.
conclusion: Birding Without Benefits is a delightful and steamy romantic comedy that combines unique elements like birding and woodworking with a heartfelt story of self-discovery and second chances. The characters are well-developed, the chemistry is electric, and the plot is both humorous and engaging. It‚Äôs a book that leaves readers eager for more from the author.

review: In this engaging story, we follow John and Celeste, both in their 40s and coming out of unsuccessful long-term relationships. John, an enthusiastic birder, partners with Celeste for a birding competition. However, a miscommunication arises: Celeste assumes they‚Äôre fake dating, while John thinks she is solely focused on the competition. The low-stakes fake dating trope proves effective, as the worst that could happen is mild embarrassment if their ruse is discovered.

John and Celeste are charming, playful, and intensely drawn to one another‚Äîqualities some readers may deem juvenile, but I found them refreshing and authentic for characters in their 40s. They grapple with relatable mid-life challenges, such as rediscovering themselves, overcoming stagnation, and adjusting to an empty nest. Celeste‚Äôs growing appreciation for birds serves as a subtle yet brilliant metaphor for her daughter leaving home.
This debut novel showcases the author's impressive storytelling skills, leaving me eager to explore more of her work in the future.

review: In this engaging story, we follow Celeste, a divorced English teacher and mother, as she embarks on a journey of self-discovery. By chance, she finds herself in a faux romance with John, an unemployed birder and woodworker grappling with his own relationship challenges. The narrative centers on their pretend dating, personal growth, and participation in a birding competition in Tucson, Arizona.

As a fellow birder, I truly appreciated the accurate species descriptions and habitat details in the story. The author‚Äôs expertise in birding lends authenticity to the book, enhancing the overall experience.

This book is a gripping read that kept me invested in the characters' journeys. I was pleasantly surprised by how the author infused a sense of *sexiness* into the world of birding, adding an unexpected yet delightful layer to the narrative.

*Birding with Benefits* is a refreshing and unique read, especially for someone like me who has never picked up a romance novel before. The combination of romance and birding creates a delightful and unexpected blend.
conclusion: *Birding with Benefits* is a unique and engaging romance novel that skillfully blends birding with personal growth and fake-dating tropes. The accurate birding details and well-developed characters make it a standout read, especially for birding enthusiasts.

review: The story centers on Celeste, a divorced mother who embarks on a journey of self-discovery and adventure. Initially sparked by a staged romance with John during a bird-watching contest, their relationship evolves into a genuine connection, challenging their resolve to remain single. Central to the narrative are themes of personal growth and rediscovery in adulthood.

**Review:**  
Celeste is a relatable and empowering character for anyone who has ever been deemed ‚Äútoo much.‚Äù John embodies a quiet confidence, blending traits of a librarian, lumberjack, and passionate birder. Supporting characters like Morgan, Celeste‚Äôs daughter; Maria, the no-nonsense friend; and Chris, the charming flirt, enrich the storyline. The romance thrives on mutual consent, open communication, and humor, creating a dynamic that is both steamy and enjoyable. Their "birders with benefits" arrangement develops into a heartfelt relationship, highlighted by a grand romantic gesture. Featuring older main characters in their late 30s and beyond, this story offers a refreshing and relatable perspective for readers in a similar age group.

The audiobook narration by Mia and Evan is outstanding, truly bringing the characters to life with their seamless delivery. The intimate scenes are skillfully executed, avoiding any cringe-worthy moments, a testament to the narrators' expertise. Their real-life partnership adds a special magic to the overall experience.

This story resonated profoundly, bringing me to tears in its final 20% through its raw vulnerability and emotional depth. The acknowledgments and note on birding added another layer of connection, enhancing the overall impact.
The book skillfully balances humor and heartfelt moments, resulting in an engaging and enjoyable read.
conclusion: This novel is a heartfelt, humorous, and steamy exploration of self-discovery, love, and connection. The well-developed characters, exceptional audiobook narration, and themes of consent, communication, and finding oneself make it a standout read. The emotional depth and relatable moments ensure it leaves a lasting impression.

review: The story centers on the unique and mature romance between two strangers in their 40s, Celeste and John, who meet at a birding competition in Tucson. Initially starting as a fake partnership, their relationship evolves into a profound connection marked by self-discovery and shared experiences. The slow-burn, friends-to-lovers dynamic is skillfully paced, emphasizing honest communication and the gradual development of both emotional and physical intimacy.

In this touching story, Celeste, a middle-school literature teacher navigating her journey of self-discovery post-divorce, helps John, a part-time woodworker and aspiring birding guide, come out of his shell. John's autistic-coded perspective subtly shapes his worldview, though it isn't the story's main focus. Both characters are kind, relatable, and their authentic growth and chemistry create a heartwarming connection. The narrative also features LGBTQ representation through secondary characters, enriching the story with depth and diversity.

The dual POV structure effectively connects readers with both protagonists, while the slow-burn romance is skillfully developed. The author's descriptive prose and keen attention to detail create an immersive and engaging experience.

Set against the stunning backdrop of southern Arizona's mountains and desert, the author masterfully weaves the landscape into the narrative, enriching the birding competition. This setting amplifies the story's themes of stillness, observation, and our connection to nature.

The novel delves into love in the later stages of life, highlighting the necessity of letting go of past baggage and fostering trust in partnerships while maintaining one's identity. It also addresses the natural distance that can develop between parents and children, exemplified by Celeste's relationship with her teenage daughter, Morgan.

The romance is both steamy and tender, emphasizing emotional intimacy and mutual respect. The characters' passion is complemented by their shared experiences and personal growth, resulting in a genuine and satisfying relationship.
conclusion: This is a refreshing and heartwarming romance that beautifully captures the possibility of love later in life. With well-crafted characters, a vivid setting, and a slow-burn romance that feels both steamy and sincere, the novel is a delightful read. Fans of authors like Emily Henry and Christina Lauren will find much to enjoy here. Highly recommended for those seeking a mature, thoughtful, and engaging love story.
reformatted_ori_review:
**Aspects:**  
- **Plot and Premise:**  
   - The story revolves around a unique and mature romance between two 40-something strangers, Celeste and John, who meet during a birding competition in Tucson.  
   - Their relationship begins as a fake partnership but evolves into a deeper connection as they navigate self-discovery and shared experiences.  
   - The slow-burn, friends-to-lovers dynamic is well-paced, with a focus on honest communication and gradual emotional and physical intimacy.  

- **Character Development:**  
   - Celeste, a middle-school literature teacher, is on a journey of self-discovery after her recent divorce. She is enthusiastic and helps John come out of his shell.  
   - John, a part-time woodworker and aspiring birding guide, is portrayed as autistic-coded, which subtly influences his worldview but isn‚Äôt the central focus of the story.  
   - Both characters are kind, caring, and relatable, with their growth and chemistry feeling authentic and heartwarming.  

- **Setting and Atmosphere:**  
   - The southern Arizona mountains and desert serve as a vivid backdrop, with the author skillfully painting the landscape and incorporating the birding competition into the narrative.  
   - The setting enhances the story‚Äôs themes of stillness, observation, and connection to nature.  

- **Themes and Messages:**  
   - The novel explores love in the second half of life, emphasizing the importance of shedding past baggage and trusting in partnership without losing oneself.  
   - It also touches on the natural distancing that can occur between parents and children, as seen in Celeste‚Äôs relationship with her teen daughter, Morgan.  

- **Representation and Inclusivity:**  
   - The story includes LGBTQ representation through secondary characters, adding depth and diversity to the narrative.  

- **Writing Style and Pacing:**  
   - The dual POV structure allows readers to connect with both protagonists, and the slow-burn romance is well-executed.  
   - The author‚Äôs descriptive prose and attention to detail make the story immersive and engaging.  

- **Romantic and Emotional Depth:**  
   - The romance is steamy yet tender, with a focus on emotional intimacy and mutual respect.  
   - The characters‚Äô passion is balanced by their shared experiences and personal growth, making their relationship feel genuine and satisfying.  

**Conclusion:**  
This is a refreshing and heartwarming romance that beautifully captures the possibility of love later in life. With well-crafted characters, a vivid setting, and a slow-burn romance that feels both steamy and sincere, the novel is a delightful read. Fans of authors like Emily Henry and Christina Lauren will find much to enjoy here. Highly recommended for those seeking a mature, thoughtful, and engaging love story.  

**Rating Scores:**  
- Not explicitly mentioned in the review, but the tone suggests a high rating, likely 4.5 or 5 stars.

review: From the very beginning, I found myself rooting for this love story. The characters' responses to each other's vulnerabilities‚Äîembracing the very things that troubled them‚Äîmade the romance feel authentic and heartwarming. This book offers a refreshing take on contemporary romance by featuring characters in their 40s and 50s, while still incorporating the banter, flirting, and spice typical of younger romances.

I loved John and Celeste in this book. The dual POV masterfully created sexual tension and chemistry, showcasing how each character was affected by the other both physically and emotionally. Their connection was absolutely a 10 out of 10. I found their self-doubt and efforts to suppress their true selves to avoid hurting one another deeply relatable and realistic. Additionally, Celeste's role as a mother added depth without consuming her entire character. I appreciated that her relationship concerns were focused on herself rather than her daughter, which felt refreshing.

The writing captivated me from the beginning, particularly with Celeste's portrayal of John as a "librarian-in-the-wild." The use of dual POV was masterfully done, intensifying both the tension and the connection between the characters.

You don't need to be a bird enthusiast to enjoy this book. As someone who is afraid of birds, I found it thoroughly enjoyable. I highly recommend it to contemporary romance fans and newcomers to the genre, especially those interested in nature or aged 40-50. It's an excellent choice for readers looking for romances featuring characters beyond the usual 20-something demographic.
conclusion: *Birding with Benefits* is a wonderfully refreshing contemporary romance with relatable, well-developed characters, a heartfelt emotional connection, and a unique perspective on love in the 40s-50s age range. The writing is engaging, the chemistry is palpable, and the story is both realistic and uplifting. I can‚Äôt wait to read more from this author!

review: The conflict between John and Celeste is both authentic and intense. John, comfortable in his own skin with Celeste, stands in stark contrast to her constant desire for him to change. Their resolution in the moment is engaging and well-crafted. I initially struggled to connect with the story, as Celeste's manic and flighty nature made it difficult to relate. Additionally, some plot twists felt either overly predictable or missed due to her self-absorption.

Review:  
John: I thoroughly enjoyed every aspect of John. His perspective, his relationship with his best friend Chris, and his quiet, observant nature all resonated with me. His competence, communication skills, and integrity truly set him apart. The author has crafted a memorable male main character.  
Celeste: On the other hand, Celeste frustrated me. Her journey of self-discovery after her divorce, coupled with her rigid belief that she must remain alone to avoid losing herself in a partner, felt excessive. Her impulsive, plan-driven personality was overwhelming, though the reactions of other characters to her behavior provided some necessary balance.

The writing is beautifully crafted, capturing emotions and intimacy with remarkable depth. However, the grand gesture near the end seemed unnecessary and could have been substituted with straightforward communication, which felt like a missed opportunity.

The exploration of self-worth and personal growth in John and Celeste's journeys is compelling. John's quiet confidence contrasts beautifully with Celeste's chaotic self-discovery, adding depth to the narrative.
conclusion: Despite a slow start and some frustrations with Celeste's character, the book grew on me. The emotional depth, beautiful writing, and well-crafted conflict between the protagonists made it a memorable read. I look forward to seeing what the author writes next.

She enters a faux relationship with John, a reserved bird enthusiast, as they team up for a bird-watching contest in Arizona. Their romance unfolds naturally, marked by undeniable chemistry and a delightful blend of humor, heartfelt moments, and a shared passion for adventure and knowledge.
The storytelling is captivating, seamlessly combining humor, warmth, and emotional depth. Its uplifting tone celebrates the beauty of nature and the transformative power of second chances.

With relatable characters, a vivid setting, and a naturally unfolding romance, the novel is a heartwarming celebration of self-discovery, second chances, and the beauty of nature. The engaging storytelling and charming characters make this a perfect read for anyone seeking an uplifting and memorable experience.

review: This charming romcom offers a unique and refreshing premise, featuring older protagonists who are overcoming past hurts and embracing new opportunities. The story follows Celeste, a middle school teacher, and John, a bird-watching enthusiast, as they form an unexpected partnership for a bird-watching contest. Key themes include personal growth, new adventures, and the evolution of their relationship, complete with enjoyable perks.

In this story, John is a quiet, thoughtful, and observant character, often misunderstood by those around him. His attractive beard adds to his charm. In contrast, Celeste is vibrant, enthusiastic, and a middle school teacher who thrives on new challenges. The dynamic between John and Celeste is compelling, as they challenge each other in unexpected ways, leading to significant personal growth. Their chemistry is palpable, with sparks flying as they navigate their partnership.

The audiobook narration by Mia Hutchinson-Shaw and Evan Sibley is commendable for its vulnerability and emotional depth. Their clear, engaging voices effectively capture the story's emotional nuances.

This story inspired me to view bird-watching as a peaceful and engaging hobby. I recommend the book to readers who appreciate themes such as bird-watching, friends-with-benefits relationships, single mom divorcees, main characters in their 40s, and quiet, thoughtful men with beards.
conclusion: This romcom is a delightful and heartwarming read with well-developed characters, a unique premise, and engaging narration. It explores themes of personal growth, new adventures, and the blossoming of an unexpected relationship. The story left me inspired to explore bird-watching and appreciate the beauty of nature.

review: I appreciated how John and Celeste openly discussed their issues with friends, though I felt they could have benefited from counseling to address their emotional baggage. Their friendships were authentic and well-developed, which I enjoyed. However, I found the relationship between Celeste and her daughter lacking; it felt too obvious, and I was disappointed that Celeste failed to recognize her own projections onto her daughter. I liked that the book didn‚Äôt rush into a marriage ending, as many romances do, making it feel realistic that the characters weren‚Äôt ready for that step. The flirting, gentle touches, and lingering thoughts over several chapters added depth to their connection and made me smile. I also appreciated the absence of a major misunderstanding or conflict in their relationship, as I often struggle with that type of story arc.
While there was some repetition in descriptions, such as her ponytail and his beard, I found it relatable, as people often fixate on specific traits they admire in others.

I resonated with Celeste's vibrant energy and enthusiasm, as well as her challenges with family and peers who tried to dampen her excitement. I appreciated her journey of rediscovering herself after years of concealing her true feelings.
conclusion: Overall, I thoroughly enjoyed this book and would read it again. The characters felt real and relatable, and their journey of self-discovery and connection was engaging. While I had some minor critiques about the mother-daughter relationship and repetitive descriptions, the authentic relationships, slow-burn romance, and thoughtful pacing made this a standout read for me.

review: The fake dating trope was executed brilliantly, and I appreciated the refreshing twist of featuring middle-aged characters instead of the usual young couples. The birding competition served as a clever plot device, while the side quests added a delightful touch of comedy. Although the third-act breakup was predictable and felt unnecessary, it didn't diminish my overall enjoyment. The story struck a perfect balance of sweet and spicy moments, and the pacing kept me thoroughly engaged.

Celeste and John shine as protagonists, beautifully contrasting yet perfectly complementing each other. John is soft-spoken and reserved, while Celeste is outgoing and outspoken, and their witty banter, complete with dad-level puns, adds a delightful touch. The small moments of intimacy‚Äîlike shared glances and fleeting touches‚Äîintensify their emotional connection. Their growth is both vast and inspiring: John learns to break free from familiarity, while Celeste learns to trust herself. The supporting characters, including Linda, Chris, and Morgan, are well-developed, and I particularly appreciated how Celeste's growth resonates through her daughter, Morgan.
The writing was exceptional, and I‚Äôm grateful for the opportunity to read an advanced copy.

I was surprised by how emotional this story made me feel. It resonated deeply, with a perfect blend of sweet and spicy moments that kept me engaged. The emotional highs and lows were beautifully balanced, making for a compelling read.
conclusion: This was an amazing read that delivered on all fronts‚Äîcharacters, plot, and emotional depth. The fake dating trope was refreshingly executed with middle-aged protagonists, and the birding competition added a unique and engaging layer to the story. Celeste and John‚Äôs growth and chemistry were beautifully portrayed, and the supporting characters added depth to the narrative. Despite the predictable third-act breakup, this book was a stellar experience, and I‚Äôll be recommending it to everyone.

review: This novel cleverly employs the fake dating trope, exploring themes of opposites attracting and the evolution of a casual relationship into something more profound. The story follows Celeste, a divorced mother of a nearly graduated child, who mistakenly agrees to pose as a stranger's girlfriend for a bird-watching contest. As their friendship blossoms into attraction, complications arise, adding depth to their evolving relationship.

Celeste is a relatable character, radiating sunshine, determination, and a knack for planning, making it easy to empathize with her and cheer her on. John, the male lead, is quiet, loyal, and skilled in woodworking, and his admiration for Celeste sets him apart. Their heartwarming dynamic showcases John as the ultimate "cinnamon roll" character, adding depth to the story.

This book is a delightful blend of humor, romance, and charm, all wrapped in a hopeful message about self-improvement. The sharp, engaging banter deserves high praise, while the romantic and emotional moments are beautifully executed, making it truly swoon-worthy.
The narrative delves into themes of self-discovery, hope, and the vital role of family and friends in personal growth.

The story skillfully balances lust and emotional connection, as characters navigate their feelings and make decisions about their future. The moderate steam level enhances the romantic tension without overshadowing the emotional core.
conclusion: This novel is a must-read for fans of later-in-life romances, offering a perfect blend of humor, romance, and emotional depth. The characters are well-developed and relatable, and the story leaves readers feeling hopeful about life and relationships.

I read romance novels for the same reason I watch birds: to find joy in a world that often offers sadness. This story was heartwarming and featured a unique plot that I truly appreciated. My favorite aspect was the relationship between Celeste and her daughter, Morgan, which felt incredibly relatable. Many readers will likely resonate with Morgan's candid remarks to her mother, even if her delivery wasn't the most tactful.
conclusion: This heartwarming and unique romance novel delivers joy and relatability, with strong character chemistry and a touching mother-daughter relationship. While the emotional depth in one key scene could have been stronger, the overall story is beautifully crafted and highly recommendable.

review: The story follows Celeste, a recently divorced woman eager to rediscover herself and embrace independence. Her journey takes an unexpected turn when she enters a fake dating arrangement with John, who needs a partner for a birding competition. This engaging premise offers a fresh twist on the fake dating trope, with the unique backdrop of birding adding originality to the narrative.

Celeste and John are well-crafted characters, each embodying relatable flaws and emotional depth. Celeste embarks on a journey of self-discovery following her marriage, while John, a quiet and kind-hearted man, grapples with feelings of undervaluation. Their dynamic is heartwarming, as they recognize each other's worth despite their insecurities. The depiction of a mature couple (not in their 20s or 30s) adds a refreshing layer to the romance. The relationship between Celeste and John is sweet and believable, rooted in their shared experiences and deep mutual understanding. Their delightful chemistry makes the journey from friendship to romance both tender and satisfying.

The writing is engaging and captivating, maintaining my interest from start to finish. The pacing strikes a perfect balance, allowing both the romance and character development to flourish. Overall, the story is a delightful page-turner, brimming with warmth and charm.

The story beautifully explores themes of self-discovery, healing from past relationships, and finding love later in life. The emotional scars of both characters are treated with sensitivity, allowing their growth and connection to feel genuine.
conclusion: This debut novel was a delightful read, combining a sweet romance with unique elements like birding and mature characters. The emotional depth, relatable themes, and engaging writing made it a standout story that left me smiling and eager for more.

review: The story follows Celeste, a recently divorced woman on a journey of self-discovery, and John, a reserved birding enthusiast. Initially set up for a fake date, they unexpectedly team up for a birding contest. This unique premise is both humorous and heartfelt, making for a delightful read.

*Celeste* is a relatable, funny, and outgoing character whose journey of self-discovery resonates deeply. Her ability to navigate her feelings for John while remaining true to herself is both heartwarming and inspiring. *John*, on the other hand, is quiet, introverted, and observant. Though stubborn, he is fair, caring, and generous. His emotional growth and the way he manages his feelings for Celeste are endearing and well-executed. The *side characters* are layered and hilarious, adding depth to the story and often propelling John and Celeste forward in their journey.
This book is a delightful blend of humor and emotional depth. Its lighthearted tone kept me laughing out loud, while the heartfelt moments were both touching and skillfully crafted.

This story explores themes of self-discovery, fake dating, and quirky romance in a fresh and relatable manner. Celeste's journey to find herself while navigating a relationship resonates with many readers.
conclusion: *Birding With Benefits* is a must-read for anyone looking for a fun, humorous, and heartwarming story. The characters are relatable and well-developed, the plot is unique and engaging, and the birding element adds a fresh and enjoyable twist. Highly recommended for fans of quirky romances, fake dating, and stories with a lot of heart.

- **Character Development:**  
  - *Celeste:* She is relatable, funny, and outgoing, with a journey of self-discovery that resonates deeply. Her ability to navigate her feelings for John while staying true to herself is heartwarming and inspiring.  
  - *John:* Quiet, introverted, and observant, John is stubborn yet fair, caring, and generous. His emotional growth and the way he handles his feelings for Celeste are endearing and well-portrayed.  
  - *Side Characters:* They are layered, hilarious, and add depth to the story, often pushing John and Celeste forward in their journey.  

- **Writing Style and Tone:**  
  The book is fun, humorous, and engaging, with a tone that balances lightheartedness and emotional depth. The humor had me laughing out loud, and the heartfelt moments were touching and well-executed.  

- **Themes and Relatability:**  
  The themes of self-discovery, fake dating, and quirky romance are explored in a way that feels fresh and relatable. Celeste‚Äôs journey of finding herself while navigating a relationship is something many readers can connect with.  

- **Unique Element (Birding):**

- **Overall Enjoyment:**  
  I thoroughly enjoyed this book and found it to be a perfect escape. It‚Äôs a quirky romance filled with laughs, surprises, and a lot of heart.  

**Conclusion:**  
*Birding With Benefits* is a must-read for anyone looking for a fun, humorous, and heartwarming story. review: This novel offers a captivating middle-aged fake dating romance with a unique twist centered on birdwatching. It follows Celeste Johansson, a forty-two-year-old language arts teacher, as she embarks on a journey of independence and self-discovery. The transition from a fake relationship to a genuine connection is skillfully portrayed, with the birdwatching competition providing a fresh and authentic backdrop.

Celeste's transformation from self-neglect to prioritizing her own needs is both compelling and relatable. Her habit of writing inspiring quotes on post-its and placing them on her bathroom mirror adds a charming dimension to her character. John Maguire, recently single and healing from a breakup, is a well-rounded character whose passion for birdwatching and aspirations of becoming a bird guide are endearing. The portrayal of both characters' fears about vulnerability and potential heartache adds depth to the story. 

The mature and well-communicated romance between Celeste and John is a highlight. Their relationship evolves naturally from pretense to genuine connection, culminating in a friends-with-benefits arrangement. The absence of miscommunication is refreshing, and their hesitations about pursuing a full-fledged relationship feel authentic given their personal circumstances.

The birding facts woven throughout the novel enhance the authenticity of the competitive backdrop. The engaging writing and the well-developed lives of Celeste and John add depth to the narrative. The resolution of the birding competition is satisfying and refreshingly avoids clich√©s.

The novel delves into themes of independence, self-discovery, and personal growth. A central focus is Celeste's journey to understand that she can prioritize herself while being in a relationship, though her hesitations can be frustrating at times. Rather than following a typical Cinderella narrative, the story presents realistic and relatable challenges faced by middle-aged individuals.
conclusion: Sarah T Dubb‚Äôs debut novel, *Birding with Benefits*, is an original and engaging story that combines a unique birdwatching premise with a mature, well-communicated romance. The characters‚Äô personal growth and realistic fears about vulnerability make the story relatable and compelling. While Celeste‚Äôs struggle to balance self-prioritization with a relationship can be frustrating, the novel‚Äôs refreshing lack of miscommunication and avoidance of clich√©s make it a standout read.

review: I approached this birding romance with skepticism, given my fear of birds, but the story quickly captivated me. The plot centers on a misunderstanding: Celeste thinks John needs her as a fake girlfriend to make his ex jealous, while he actually requires a partner for a birding competition. As their fake relationship develops, it transforms into a genuine connection, seamlessly blending humor, chemistry, and emotional depth.

Celeste‚Äôs vibrant energy beautifully contrasts with John‚Äôs steady and kind demeanor, creating a captivating dynamic. Their undeniable chemistry evolves into a playful ‚Äúbirding with benefits‚Äù arrangement, adding charm to the narrative. The secondary characters, particularly John‚Äôs friend Chris, are memorable, and I would love to see a book centered on him. However, Celeste‚Äôs emotional journey could have been more developed. Her fear of losing herself in relationships stems from her past marriage, but the specifics of that experience and her ex‚Äôs role remain vague. It seems Celeste could benefit from therapy, especially given her tendency to impose her plans on her daughter, Morgan, and even John. Meanwhile, John appears stagnant, with unclear aspirations for his woodworking business and birdwatching teaching. His prolonged relationship with Breena, despite their evident mismatch, also lacks sufficient explanation.
This novel is both charming and moving, blending contemporary romance with humor and emotional depth. The author's engaging writing style leaves me eager to see what they create next.

Set in Tucson, AZ, the story presents a diverse cast of characters and addresses several sensitive topics, including past divorce, toxic relationships, infidelity, acephobia (which is not addressed), recent layoffs, ableist language, and gendered pejoratives.
conclusion: This debut novel is a delightful and heartfelt contemporary romance with a unique birding twist. While the emotional arcs and character motivations could have been more developed, the charming dynamics between Celeste and John, along with the strong secondary characters, make it a memorable read. I look forward to more from this author.

   - Their fake dating evolves into a genuine connection, blending humor, chemistry, and emotional depth.  

- **Character Dynamics:**  
   - Celeste‚Äôs irrepressible energy complements John‚Äôs steady and kind presence, creating a compelling dynamic.  
   - Their chemistry is undeniable, and their relationship evolves into a ‚Äúbirding with benefits‚Äù situation, which adds a playful and charming layer to the story.  
   - The secondary characters, like John‚Äôs friend Chris, are standout additions, and I‚Äôd love to see a book focused on him.  

- **Character Development:**  
   - Celeste‚Äôs emotional arc could have been more fleshed out. Her fear of losing herself in relationships is tied to her past marriage, but the details of how it happened or whether her ex was truly at fault remain unclear.  
   - I felt Celeste could benefit from therapy, especially given her tendency to be a smothering mom, imposing her plans on her daughter Morgan and even John to some extent.  
   - John‚Äôs character feels stuck in inertia, with unclear plans for his woodworking business or birdwatching teaching aspirations. His prolonged relationship with Breena, despite their obvious mismatch, also lacked sufficient explanation.  

- **Setting and Representation:**  
   - The story is set in Tucson, AZ, and features a diverse cast of characters.  
   - Content notes include past divorce, toxic ex, infidelity, acephobia (not countered), recent layoff, and other sensitive topics like ableist language and gendered pejoratives.  

- **Writing Style and Tone:**  
   - The novel is incredibly charming and moving, with a contemporary romance tone that balances humor and emotional depth.  
   - The author‚Äôs writing style is engaging, and I‚Äôm excited to see what they write next.  

**Conclusion:**  
This debut novel is a delightful and heartfelt contemporary romance with a unique birding twist. While the emotional arcs and character motivations could have been more developed, the charming dynamics between Celeste and John, along with the strong secondary characters, make it a memorable read. I look forward to more from this author.  

**Rating Scores:**  
(No specific rating scores mentioned in the review.)

review: The characters' actions do not reflect the mindset of serious birders. For example, one character spots a new species but refrains from mentioning it to avoid disrupting their partner's appreciation of nature. As a birder with a life list of over 600, I find this unrealistic; a true birder would prioritize adding to their list over such considerations.
conclusion: The novel is charming and enjoyable for casual readers or those with a passing interest in birding. However, for someone deeply immersed in the birding world, the portrayal of the competition and the characters‚Äô behavior feels unrealistic and lacks the authenticity of a true birder‚Äôs dedication.
reformatted_ori_review:
**Aspects:**  
- **Realism of the Birding Competition:**  
  The portrayal of the birding competition feels unrealistic to me. As someone deeply involved in birding, I find it hard to believe that the main characters could casually participate and think they stand a chance at winning. Serious birders would be far more dedicated‚Äîconstantly checking eBird for sightings, waking up at 4 am, driving long distances, and spending hours waiting for a single sighting. They would also bird before and after work and drop everything for a rare sighting.  

- **Character Behavior and Motivation:**  
  The characters‚Äô behavior doesn‚Äôt align with the mindset of a serious birder. For instance, one character sees a new species but chooses not to mention it to avoid interrupting their partner‚Äôs awe of nature. This feels unrealistic to me, as a birder with a life list of over 600 would prioritize adding to their list over such considerations.  

- **Authenticity of the Birding Experience:**  
  While the story is cute and enjoyable for casual birders, it lacks the depth and obsession that define serious birders. The main character‚Äôs aspiration to guide professionally feels unconvincing without demonstrating the obsessive, list-driven behavior typical of professional birders.  

**Conclusion:**  
The novel is charming and enjoyable for casual readers or those with a passing interest in birding. However, for someone deeply immersed in the birding world, the portrayal of the competition and the characters‚Äô behavior feels unrealistic and lacks the authenticity of a true birder‚Äôs dedication.

review: While the third-act breakup wasn't my favorite moment, I understood Celeste's reaction given her background. review: The book offers enjoyable moments, but ultimately, it doesn't meet expectations. While the author demonstrates promise, the story fails to fully realize its potential. However, the opposites-attract trope was well-executed. Celeste, a free-spirited extrovert, and John, a controlled introvert, balanced each other beautifully, creating a dynamic that was one of the story's highlights.
The concept of a romance centered on bird-watching is both appealing and unique. As someone who has recently developed an interest in birds, I found this idea particularly enjoyable.
conclusion: Overall, *Birding with Benefits* was an enjoyable read with a unique premise and some strong elements, such as the opposites-attract dynamic and the fun bird-watching theme. However, the lack of character chemistry and the forced nature of certain scenes held it back from being a standout romance. Despite its flaws, the author shows potential, and I look forward to seeing what she writes next.

review: The heroine posed a significant challenge for me. She resembled a stereotypical manic pixie dream girl, overflowing with quirks that felt unrealistic and exaggerated. For example, her antics‚Äîsuch as running late after getting lost in a podcast about grilled cheese or needing a ride halfway to Mexico after attempting to walk a day‚Äôs distance‚Äîmade her less relatable and more like a caricature.

The heroine's behavior frequently disrupted my immersion in the story, as it felt disconnected from how real people typically act. While the narrative acknowledges her overwhelming personality by explicitly labeling her as "a lot," this self-awareness doesn't render her quirks more endearing; rather, it underscores why some might find her exhausting.
The novel's premise is both fun and unique, especially in its take on forced proximity, which I found engaging and refreshing.
conclusion: While the novel's premise was enjoyable and inventive, the heroine's overly quirky and unrealistic behavior detracted from my overall reading experience. Her characterization felt exaggerated and at times frustrating, which made it harder to fully immerse myself in the story.

- **Premise and Concept:**

- **Characterization (Heroine):**  
  The heroine, however, was a significant point of struggle for me. She came across as a stereotypical "manic pixie dream girl" with an overabundance of quirks. For instance, her actions, like running late because she got engrossed in a podcast about grilled cheese or needing to be picked up halfway to Mexico after deciding to see how far she could walk in a day, felt unrealistic and exaggerated. These traits made her character feel less relatable and more like a caricature.

- **Realism and Relatability:**  
  The heroine's behavior often pulled me out of the story because it didn't align with how real people typically act. Even if such people exist, the narrative seemed to acknowledge that her personality could be overwhelming, as it explicitly labeled her as "a lot." This self-awareness didn't make her quirks more endearing; instead, it highlighted why some might find her exhausting.

**Conclusion:**  
While the novel's premise was enjoyable and inventive, the heroine's overly quirky and unrealistic behavior detracted from my overall reading experience. Her characterization felt exaggerated and at times frustrating, which made it harder to fully immerse myself in the story.

review: The story centers on a six-week birding challenge, providing a unique and charming backdrop for the romance. With its low angst and rich birding content, the narrative offers a light and enjoyable reading experience.

Celeste, a vibrant 42-year-old divorced single mom, embodies determination and independence. Her choice to volunteer as a fake girlfriend for a stranger highlights her bold and energetic personality, which I found both relatable and refreshing. The tension between her desire for independence and her undeniable chemistry with John creates a compelling narrative. John, characterized by his quiet, deliberate nature and meticulous passion for birding, adds depth to the story. His attentiveness in his interactions with Celeste enhances their dynamic, making it engaging. Their chemistry is palpable, and the decision to become "birders with benefits" introduces a unique and enjoyable twist to their relationship. The spice in their interactions is well-crafted and satisfying.
The writing was engaging and consistently maintained a light, fun tone. The blend of humor, romance, and birding details kept me thoroughly entertained.
conclusion: Overall, *Birding with Benefits* was a delightful and low-angst romance with a unique premise. Celeste‚Äôs vibrant energy and John‚Äôs meticulous care made their relationship enjoyable to follow. While the parent-daughter subplot didn‚Äôt fully land for me, the rest of the story, including the spice and birding theme, made for a highly entertaining read.

Her journey of balancing her desire for independence with her undeniable chemistry with John was compelling.  

- **Character Development (John):**  
  John is depicted as quiet, deliberate, and meticulous, particularly in his passion for birding. His attentiveness and care in his interactions with Celeste added depth to his character and made their dynamic engaging.  

- **Romantic Chemistry:**  
  The chemistry between Celeste and John is undeniable, and their decision to become "birders with benefits" added a unique and enjoyable twist to their relationship. The spice in their interactions was well-written and satisfying.  

- **Plot and Setting:**  
  The story revolves around a six-week birding challenge, which serves as a unique and charming backdrop for the romance. The low-angst, high-bird-content narrative made for a light and enjoyable read.  

- **Parent-Child Relationship:**  
  While I appreciated Celeste's role as a single mom, the subplot involving her teenage daughter didn‚Äôt fully resonate with me. It felt less developed compared to other aspects of the story.  

- **Writing Style and Tone:**  
  The writing was engaging and maintained a light, fun tone throughout. The balance of humor, romance, and birding details kept me entertained.  

**Conclusion:**

review: The story begins on a fun and engaging note, but it also delves into moments of angst and drama, particularly influenced by Celeste's personality and her relationships with others. The third act features some exaggerated moments that could have been toned down. The plot centers on Celeste and John, two newly divorced individuals in their forties who meet through a mutual friend. Initially, Celeste believes John needs a fake girlfriend for an event, only to learn he actually requires a partner for a bird-watching tournament in Tucson. This six-week competition, which includes weekends spent birdwatching, serves as the story's backbone. The dynamic between Celeste and John, along with their interactions with other teams‚Äîespecially John's ex and her partner‚Äîadds both fun and competitiveness to the narrative.

John is an exceptional male lead, one of the best I‚Äôve encountered. His passion for birdwatching and woodworking, combined with his calm and knowledgeable demeanor, makes him an engaging character. In contrast, Celeste is enthusiastic and competitive, but she occasionally comes off as overly controlling, which I found slightly irritating. The supporting characters, like John‚Äôs best friend Chris, who works with endangered baby snails, add charm, though they could have been more fully developed. The romance between Celeste and John unfolds gradually as they interact during the competition and attend social events, such as Celeste‚Äôs teacher gatherings. Their chemistry is palpable, and their shared experiences foster a bond, even amidst their initial hesitations about starting a new relationship.

The birdwatching scenes are truly memorable and enjoyable. The vivid descriptions of nature, combined with John's passion for helping others appreciate their surroundings, create an immersive atmosphere. Additionally, the Tucson setting for the birdwatching tournament provides a unique and refreshing backdrop to the story.
conclusion: Overall, this is a lovely story with a unique premise centered around birdwatching. The memorable nature scenes, the standout character of John, and the gradual development of the romance make it an enjoyable read. While some of Celeste‚Äôs traits and the third-act drama were slightly off-putting, the book is recommended for readers who appreciate a romance with beautiful nature walks and a touch of competitiveness.

review:
I found Celeste to be a relatable character on her journey of self-discovery, whether after a divorce or while still in a relationship. Her story resonated with me as it emphasizes the importance of authenticity and not conforming to others' expectations. I often feel "too much" and have been encouraged to tone myself down, making Celeste's empowering journey feel personal.

However, I found John‚Äôs character less believable. While I appreciated his attentiveness and detail-oriented nature, the combination of his "man's man" lumberjack persona with extreme social awkwardness and academic tendencies felt inconsistent. It was hard to accept that someone with only one long-term relationship‚Äîwhere his partner "wore the pants"‚Äîwould possess such refined romantic and intimate skills. 

Additionally, it seemed unrealistic for Celeste, who had been diminished by men in her past, to feel so comfortable being her vibrant self around John, who is quiet and socially awkward. Their deep understanding of each other without much verbal communication felt implausible; personally, I would find such a dynamic more uncomfortable than thrilling.

I appreciated the themes of stillness, connection with nature, and competition in the story, which added depth and charm. The romance trope of resisting feelings before ultimately giving in was both enjoyable and well-executed.
conclusion: While I had some issues with the realism of John‚Äôs character and the dynamics between him and Celeste, I found Celeste‚Äôs journey of self-discovery deeply relatable and empowering. The themes of nature, stillness, and competition, along with the slow-burn romance, made the book enjoyable overall.

review: John and Celeste's journey of emotional healing is beautifully enriched by the support of their friends and family. Standout characters Chris and Maria, especially Maria, offer profound insights, with her advice to Celeste to ‚Äútry to be your own friend‚Äù resonating deeply and highlighting the importance of self-love. The slow-burn romance between John and Celeste is captivating, marked by breathtaking intimacy. A standout moment occurs when the quieter John reveals his vulnerability in the bedroom, adding intensity and passion to their relationship.

This story is a gentle and heartfelt exploration of bravery, self-discovery, and the courage to embrace new possibilities. It thoughtfully addresses the emotional wounds and baggage from past relationships, highlighting how John felt ‚Äúnot enough‚Äù and Celeste was labeled ‚Äútoo much.‚Äù The third-act breakup is skillfully executed, serving as a crucial turning point for both characters to gain clarity and rediscover themselves.
The birding aspect was enjoyable and inspiring, igniting a desire to pursue the hobby. The story's skillful integration of discovery, joy, and magic into everyday life was a standout element.
conclusion: *Birding with Benefits* is a heartfelt, swoon-worthy novel that masterfully balances emotional depth, character growth, and a slow-burn romance. It‚Äôs a story about healing, self-discovery, and finding love, with moments of joy and magic that linger long after reading. The birding theme adds a unique charm, and the supporting characters, especially Chris and Maria, enrich the narrative with their wisdom and warmth.

review: The story was an enjoyable, light read. I appreciated the pacing, but I believe the romance could have been enhanced with more meaningful conversations.

Celeste, a 42-year-old divorced mother and middle school teacher, serves as a relatable protagonist rediscovering her identity post-marriage. Her journey of self-discovery is compellingly portrayed. John, a kind-hearted bird lover with dreams of starting a bird tour business, adds depth to the story with his patience and passion for nature. The evolution of Celeste and John's relationship‚Äîfrom fake dating to friends, then friends with benefits, and ultimately something deeper‚Äîwas enjoyable to witness. However, I would have preferred more conversations highlighting their emotional growth instead of additional intimate scenes. The mother-daughter subplot was well-executed and authentically captured the challenges faced by someone of Celeste‚Äôs age.

The Tucson, Arizona setting, with its hiking trails and vibrant nature descriptions, adds a unique and immersive layer to the story. The birding competition, along with the detailed accounts of bird identification, sounds, and activities, was a standout feature, particularly for a birding enthusiast like me.
This novel's emphasis on self-discovery, nature, and love is both refreshing and engaging. The portrayal of two main characters over 40 offers a rare and welcome representation in the romance genre.
conclusion: This was an enjoyable and heartwarming read with a unique focus on birding and nature. The characters were well-developed, and the setting was vividly described. While I would have liked more emotional depth in the romance, the story‚Äôs themes of self-discovery and the representation of older protagonists made it a standout.

This novel beautifully combines summer sweetness with the sultry essence of Arizona, creating a delightful reading experience. Set against the backdrop of the Arizona birding community, the love story feels both unique and inspiring. conclusion: This novel was an absolute delight, blending a unique setting, relatable characters, and a heartfelt love story with a strong connection to nature. review: I admired everything Celeste represented, but I felt she could have benefited from therapy after her divorce and during her self-discovery journey. Having experienced two unsuccessful long-term relationships myself, I understand her struggles. However, I can't fathom shutting off my desire for love, even after being cheated on. The conflict with Morgan frustrated me, and I believe therapy could have helped Celeste navigate that situation more effectively. On the other hand, I absolutely loved John‚Äîhe was an exceptional book boyfriend, deserving of an A++++ rating. Most men should aspire to be like him, and I appreciated his character growth throughout the story. The name of his new business brought me to tears, yet I felt Celeste overlooked its significance, despite its connection to her values.
conclusion: This was an excellent book with strong character development, particularly for John, and relatable themes of love, heartbreak, and self-discovery. While Celeste‚Äôs journey was compelling, her lack of therapy and her handling of Morgan‚Äôs future were areas that could have been improved. Despite these minor critiques, the book is highly recommended.

   - The conflict with Morgan irritated me, and I feel like therapy could have helped Celeste navigate that aspect better.

   - This book was fantastic in so many ways. As a whole, I 100% recommend it.  
   - I cannot thank NetGalley and the publisher enough for the ARC in exchange for an honest review.  

**Conclusion:**  
This was an excellent book with strong character development, particularly for John, and relatable themes of love, heartbreak, and self-discovery. Despite these minor critiques, the book is highly recommended.

review: The novel follows Celeste, a divorced single mother in her 40s, who reluctantly joins a bird-watching competition at a friend's urging. There, she encounters John, a sensitive and reserved birdwatcher and woodworker. Their decision to fake date soon ignites genuine chemistry between them. The story is heartwarming, fun, and quirky, offering a fresh perspective on the world of bird watching.

Celeste‚Äôs journey of self-discovery is captivating as she navigates the weight of feeling ‚Äútoo much‚Äù for others and the remnants of her failed marriage. John, an introvert, is equally relatable, grappling with feelings of inadequacy. Their personal growth and mutual support form the heart of their bond. The romance between Celeste and John is beautifully crafted, featuring tender moments, playful banter, and profound emotional connections. While their shared passion for birding brings them together, it is their emotional development that truly solidifies their relationship. The supporting cast, including quirky fellow birdwatchers and close friends, enriches the narrative, fostering a sense of community and camaraderie that enhances the overall reading experience.

The author masterfully blends romance with humor and warmth, creating a charming narrative that seamlessly intertwines lighthearted moments with deeper emotional themes. The engaging writing style fosters a strong connection to the characters and their journeys.

This novel explores not only the quest for love but also the journey of self-discovery and the appreciation of nature's beauty. It emphasizes personal growth, understanding, and the joy that comes from shared passions.
conclusion: This delightful debut novel is a heartwarming and quirky story about love, self-discovery, and the beauty of nature. With well-developed characters, a charming romance, and a vibrant supporting cast, it‚Äôs a book that balances humor and warmth beautifully. Highly recommended for fans of Christina Lauren and those who enjoy love stories with a touch of the outdoors.

review: The birding storyline was refreshing and enjoyable, providing a unique twist on typical narratives. The fake relationship premise was engaging, as Celeste and John teamed up to support each other‚ÄîCeleste partnering with John in a birding contest to advance his career, while John attended Celeste's social and work events to ease her personal pressures. Their friends-with-benefits arrangement introduced an intriguing dynamic, and the gradual development of their relationship and chemistry was skillfully executed.

Celeste and John both grapple with emotional baggage‚ÄîCeleste from her divorce and John from a breakup and feelings of inadequacy. While Celeste's reluctance to enter a new relationship is understandable, it occasionally feels excessive and hinders her growth. In contrast, John, though also struggling, is more willing to move forward, making him a more proactive character. The opposites-attract dynamic is effectively portrayed, with Celeste's vibrant, lively nature complementing John's reserved, grumpy demeanor. Their contrasting personalities create a compelling balance in the story.

The novel skillfully delves into themes of opposites attracting, the complexities of fake relationships, and the challenges of divorce. The presence of a teenage child enriches the narrative, adding depth to the overall story.
conclusion: *Birding With Benefits* was an enjoyable and unique read, blending a fun birding storyline with a slow-burn romance. While the characters had their flaws, their chemistry and the opposites-attract dynamic made the story engaging. The themes of personal growth and overcoming emotional baggage added depth, making it a worthwhile read despite some minor frustrations with the characters.

The use of tropes‚Äîsuch as fake dating, making an ex jealous, the divorcee/single mom dynamic, and the classic "you idiots love each other" scenario‚Äîwas effective and enriched the overall depth of the story.

Celeste's quest for stability post-divorce and her apprehension about her feelings for John infused the story with emotional depth. Her journey was both genuine and relatable. Overall, the narrative was warm, lovely, and enjoyable, striking a perfect balance of humor, heart, and spice.

review: This story follows Celeste, a woman who is decluttering her life post-divorce by seeking out things that spark joy. Her journey leads her to meet John in the park, whom she mistakenly believes needs a romantic partner to make his ex jealous. In reality, John is looking for a partner for a six-week bird-watching contest.

On paper, she and John seemed mismatched: she was loud and open, while he was quiet and private. Yet, in their shared moments‚Äîhiking the trail, reading on his couch, or cuddling in bed‚Äîthey fit together effortlessly, like a puzzle piece snapping into place. What they shared transcended mere chemistry; it felt like a biological connection, as natural as breath and skin. Their birding adventures were filled with fun, flirtation, teasing, stolen kisses, and quiet high-fives, making their bond all the more special.
I thoroughly enjoyed this story and will eagerly seek out more works by this author in the future.
conclusion: This novel is a delightful blend of charming character dynamics, a unique and engaging premise, and a slow-burn romance filled with playful moments. The chemistry between Celeste and John feels natural and deeply rooted, making their journey both heartwarming and memorable. The author‚Äôs storytelling style is captivating, leaving me eager to explore more of their work.

review: Overall, I found the plot to be unique, though I would have appreciated even more focus on birding.

John stood out as my favorite character, but I was disappointed by the overall lack of character development. The main characters often felt unrealistic, as they didn't behave their age. Celeste, in particular, came across as immature and unlikable.

The writing style felt more suited to young adult fiction, while the themes were distinctly adult. I would have preferred the characters to engage in their deep conversations with one another rather than with their friends.
As a bird enthusiast (Go Wingspan!), I was drawn to both the cover and concept of this book. I particularly enjoyed the bird contest element.
conclusion: While I had mixed emotions about this book, I appreciated its unique plot and the bird-related elements. However, the lack of character development, the mismatch between the writing style and content, and the unlikable portrayal of some characters left me wanting more.

   - I love birds (Go Wingsspan!) and really liked the cover and idea of this book.  
   - The bird contest was one of the aspects I enjoyed.  

- **Character Development and Likability:**  
   - John was by far my favorite character.  
   - The lack of character development was disappointing.  
   - I had a hard time picturing the main characters because they didn‚Äôt act their age.  
   - Celeste acted immature, and I didn‚Äôt find her to be a very likable character.  

- **Writing Style and Tone:**  
   - Oddly, the writing felt YA, but the content was adult.  
   - I wish the deep talks were had with each other instead of their friends.  

- **Plot and Themes:**  
   - Overall, I thought the plot was unique.  
   - I wish there had been even more birding!  

**Conclusion:**  
While I had mixed emotions about this book, I appreciated its unique plot and the bird-related elements. However, the lack of character development, the mismatch between the writing style and content, and the unlikable portrayal of some characters left me wanting more.

review: I thoroughly enjoyed the first half of the story, but the second half felt somewhat stagnant. It became repetitive, with certain points being discussed in circles, and the excessive sexual content grew tiresome. However, the birding and competition added an engaging framework to the narrative. I appreciated the secondary characters and wished we could have explored them further.

The backstories were compelling, and the characters had good depth, though I felt they could have been explored more thoroughly in the second half. I appreciated the portrayal of the middle-aged characters, who were not starting over but were deeply entrenched in their journeys. Their contrasting personalities created a dynamic that effectively challenged one another. While the third act was frustrating due to the characters' struggles to understand themselves and each other, the self-discovery was ultimately rewarding, even if it felt somewhat superficial.
conclusion: While the novel had some pacing issues in the second half and could have delved deeper into character development, it was an entertaining read overall. The middle-aged protagonists, their dynamic, and the unique birding competition framework stood out as highlights.

- **Character Development:**  
   - The backstories were great, and the characters had decent depth, but I think they could have been explored more deeply in the second half.  
   - I appreciated the middle-aged characters and where they were in their lives‚Äînot starting fresh but fully ensconced in their journeys. Their polar opposite personalities were a great dynamic to shake each other up.  
   - The third act brought some frustrations as the characters failed to understand each other and themselves, but the self-discovery was rewarding, even if it felt a touch too shallow.  

- **Plot and Themes:**  
   - The birding and competition provided a fun frame for the story.  
   - I enjoyed the secondary characters and wished we got more of them.  

- **Overall Enjoyment:**

**Conclusion:**

review: The initial misunderstanding between Celeste and John was both hilarious and expertly crafted. The story shines in its portrayal of their mutual pining and slow-burn romance. The final third unfolds seamlessly, featuring a conflict that feels organic and avoids unnecessary prolongation. The grand gesture in the last chapter is both swoon-worthy and uplifting.

John is a kind and calm character whose journey to rebuild his self-worth after a damaging relationship is compelling. Celeste‚Äôs self-doubts and her struggle to reclaim her identity post-divorce are well-crafted and relatable. I empathized with her daughter, Morgan, who often felt overshadowed by Celeste‚Äôs enthusiasm regarding college. Supporting characters like Chris, John‚Äôs best friend, and Linda and Maria, Celeste‚Äôs friends, add depth to the narrative. Chris‚Äôs supportive nature and meaningful conversations with John are particularly endearing, while Maria‚Äôs candidness about her ‚Äúrules‚Äù offers a refreshing perspective. The chemistry between Celeste and John is palpable from the beginning, highlighted by a sublime scene where they take selfies with a dove, complete with swoon-worthy glances. The intimacy between them feels earned and is beautifully executed, especially in Chapters 25 and 26.
The writing was engaging, and the romance unfolded at a satisfying slow burn. The dialogue felt natural, and the emotional moments were handled with authenticity and care.
As a bird lover, I appreciated the exploration of Arizona's native birds and the unique charm of the bird-watching contest setting.

This story powerfully explores the theme of reclaiming one's identity and the importance of embracing life with a "yes." I found Celeste's motivational post-it notes, especially "Say yes" and "Be brave," to be particularly inspiring. The poignant examination of how past relationships can erode self-worth, especially in John's case, struck a chord with me. The book emphasizes the necessity of staying true to oneself within a relationship, a message that resonated deeply.
conclusion: This was a delightful, swoony, and uplifting romance that balanced humor, emotional depth, and a satisfying slow-burn relationship. The characters were well-developed, and their journeys of self-discovery and healing were relatable and inspiring. The supporting cast added richness to the story, and the themes of reclaiming one‚Äôs identity and learning to trust oneself were beautifully explored. A heartwarming read with just the right amount of heat.

review: The first half of the book is engaging and entertaining, with the birding competition at its core. However, the second half loses momentum as the focus shifts away from birding, making the story feel less compelling.

Celeste is a vibrant and relatable protagonist, making her journey of self-discovery both engaging and entertaining. John, the quiet, cinnamon roll-type male lead, exudes a rustic, librarian-in-the-wild charm, though I wished for a deeper exploration of his character. The dynamic between Celeste and John is delightful, as their contrasting personalities create strong chemistry. Additionally, Celeste‚Äôs relationship with her daughter adds depth to her character, even if it isn‚Äôt a central focus of the story.
The book exudes an upbeat and fun vibe, featuring a lighthearted tone that makes it a delightful read. The writing is engaging and immersive, especially during the birding scenes.
The Arizona wilderness serves as an inviting and immersive backdrop, enriching the story. The birding competition and outdoor adventures stand out, bringing the setting to life.

The story effectively explores themes of self-discovery, new adventures, and finding joy in unexpected places. It beautifully conveys the message of embracing life's quirks and discovering happiness in small moments.

Although I don't often read rom-coms, I found this book to be both delightful and entertaining. It inspired me to pay closer attention to the birds in my local area. While the second half wasn't as strong as the first, I still enjoyed the overall experience and look forward to the author's next project.
This book presents a unique and quirky premise, blending romance with a bird-watching competition. The evolution of a fake relationship into something deeper is both engaging and refreshing.
conclusion: *Birding with Benefits* is a quirky, refreshing rom-com with a unique premise and memorable characters. The Arizona wilderness setting and birding competition add charm, and the chemistry between Celeste and John is undeniable. While the second half of the book loses some momentum, the overall story is delightful and uplifting, leaving me eager to see what the author writes next.

review: I was pleasantly surprised by how much I enjoyed this story. While it initially seemed cute and fun, it had a unique depth that set it apart. The drama was handled maturely and realistically, which I appreciated. The quirky setting, especially the birding aspect, added to the charm. Although there was a third-act breakup, it was refreshingly free of miscommunication; the characters openly discussed their feelings and ended things amicably, even though they were both left feeling miserable.

I thoroughly enjoyed the main characters, Celeste and John, both of whom grapple with personal baggage that leads to significant character growth. Even minor characters, like the woman who attends therapy and offers an apology, demonstrate development. The chemistry between Celeste and John was palpable, and I found myself rooting for their romance from the start. Their interactions had me giggling, swooning, and fanning myself‚Äîit's a testament to the author's skill in capturing chemistry.

I also appreciated the casual representation of LGBT+ characters. Celeste's daughter is best friends with a nonbinary person, and their relationship is portrayed as completely normal. Additionally, Chris appears to be bisexual, dating Greg while also showing interest in women. This normalization of diverse identities is refreshing and should be the standard.

The spice in the story was enjoyable, but I was left disappointed by the absence of a final sex scene or an epilogue. Overall, it was a great read!
conclusion: Overall, I was very happy with this purchase and highly recommend it. While I‚Äôm not 100% sure if I‚Äôll read it again, I enjoyed myself IMMENSELY. The supporting characters also shine, providing strong friendships and offering honest advice and encouragement, which enriches the overall depth of the story.

The author's passion for birding is evident in the vivid and joyful scenes throughout the story. The afterword highlights their personal connection to both birding and romance novels, adding an authentic touch to the narrative.

This book captures a sense of childlike joy and discovery, especially through the characters' passion for birding. It brought me smiles and laughter, compelling me to keep reading with its lighthearted yet steamy tone. The portrayal of healthy support systems and journeys of self-discovery is both heartwarming and satisfying.

This steamy rom-com features adults in their 40s, offering a refreshing and mature perspective. The narrative cleverly intertwines romance with the unique hobby of birding, resulting in a quirky and enjoyable read. The inclusion of a competition trope adds to the engaging and dynamic pacing of the story.
conclusion: ‚ÄúBirding with Benefits‚Äù is a delightful and unique rom-com that combines mature romance, quirky hobbies, and heartfelt relationships. review: I appreciated the inclusion of 40-year-old characters, as it offers a realistic and relatable portrayal of romance for readers in their 30s, 40s, and beyond. The story demonstrates that love at this age can be just as passionate and engaging as in younger romances. However, I would have liked to see more interaction with the protagonist‚Äôs daughter. Her presence felt underutilized, leaving me wanting greater depth in that aspect of the narrative.
The relationship drama occasionally fell into clich√©s, echoing elements of YA writing. Although the overall execution was strong, these moments slightly undermined the story's cohesion.

Although the story is set in Tucson, the author missed an opportunity to fully explore the location. More specific references to local landmarks would have enriched the setting and added authenticity. As it stands, the backdrop feels somewhat generic and could easily represent any city.

The premise of fake-daters entering a birding competition is refreshingly unique. I was initially skeptical about its execution, but it cleverly fosters chemistry between the characters. The revelation that one of them has a passion for birding adds an unexpected depth to the story.
conclusion: Overall, I thoroughly enjoyed this novel and found it to be a unique and engaging read. The premise, character representation, and intimate scenes were standout elements, though the setting could have been more vividly portrayed, and the drama occasionally felt clich√©d. Despite these minor flaws, I would happily read more from this author.

review: The main character (MC) is well-developed, and her journey of self-discovery is truly inspiring. Her best friend, a clever and supportive figure, cleverly encourages the MC to give herself advice, which I found both touching and insightful. The advice she offers‚Äî‚ÄúWe‚Äôre all works in progress. You aren‚Äôt a destination, but a process. You‚Äôre always a discovery. Trust yourself more; you control your path, and your past doesn‚Äôt define your future‚Äù‚Äîis particularly moving. I also appreciated the MC‚Äôs habit of placing inspiring Post-its on her bathroom mirror, which made her feel relatable and connected to me.

This book is eloquently written and a delight for nature lovers. The Author‚Äôs Note, though positioned at the end, features a memorable line from the main character's romantic interest: ‚ÄúStart with discovery, and go from there.‚Äù This sentiment resonated with me so deeply that I intend to display it on my mirror.

The book features some steamy moments that enhance the overall narrative. One line that particularly resonated with me was, ‚ÄúYes, it would be easy to fall into real relationship territory with John. But it had been easy with Peter. Easy to fall, harder to climb back up, and more difficult still to grow once out of that shadow.‚Äù This reminded me of a personal experience where I expressed similar feelings to an ex, only to have my heart broken when he left unexpectedly. The exploration of love and heartbreak in the story reflects my own hesitations about re-entering relationships, making it both relatable and emotionally impactful.
conclusion: *Birders with Benefits* is a beautifully written novel that combines romance, emotional depth, and relatable characters. The story‚Äôs exploration of love, heartbreak, and self-discovery resonated with me, and the MC‚Äôs journey felt both inspiring and authentic. I enjoyed the book immensely and would love to see more of the daughter‚Äôs story in a potential sequel.
